awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Analyzing Information Leak in Smart Homes
awd_abstract_narration:
With the rapid adoption of the Internet of Things (IoT), we face a new world, where we are never alone. At all times, a plethora of connected devices, from smartphones to home assistants to motion detectors continuously sense and monitor our activities. While these devices provide us convenience, they are often backed by powerful analytics to sift through large volume of personal data, at times collected without our awareness or consent. Such personal data can reveal a lot about ourselves like our habits and lifestyles, which not only has great commercial value to advertisers to serve targeted ads, but can also be misused by insurance companies, repressive governments and cybercriminals. The goal of this project is to build a foundation for understanding the different ways in which every day Internet of Things devices can leak sensitive information about our lifestyles. The proposed work will benefit the society as a whole as people will become more aware of the security and privacy risks associated with household Internet of Things devices. The proposal can also help identify vulnerable communication protocols and consequentially lead to the design of new privacy-enhancing protocols. Furthermore, this project will expose both undergraduate and graduate students to cutting-edge analytic tools and help develop a globally competitive science, technology, engineering and mathematics workforce.

This project proposes to build a testbed to analyze the extent to which household Internet of Things devices can leak sensitive information about ourselves. The proposed testbed will facilitate research along the following directions: i) help determine the feasibility of performing side-channel attacks to infer not only what devices reside inside a household, but also what higher order activities users may be performing, for example, inferring whether a user is making a call using Amazon Alexa or taking a nap, or working out on a treadmill; ii) help determine what data is collected and with whom it is shared; iii) help build an information dashboard to notify users about the potential privacy risks. Building a scalable testbed that can interact with a wide variety of devices will require addressing a host of systems related challenges. The data analysis will utilize a variety of advanced statistical, signal processing and machine learning techniques. This project will provide a much-needed insight into the security and privacy threats imposed by emerging Internet of Things devices. The proposed work can lead to not only identifying devices that leak sensitive information, but at the same time foster the design of new privacy-enhancing technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We live in an increasingly connected world where we spend much of our time interacting with many Internet of Things (IoT) devices. Examples of such IoT devices include smart voice assistants, smart surveillance cameras, smart TVs, smart thermostats, smartwatches, and smart scales. While all these IoT devices provide convenience through the automation of appliances, such convenience often comes at the cost of sharing very personal data about our lifestyle. With such data harvesting potential over time, it becomes challenging to keep up with the many different ways in which data about ourselves is collected and used.

This project built a testbed to analyze how household IoT devices can leak sensitive information about ourselves. The testbed facilitated research along with the following directions: i) help determine the feasibility of performing side-channel attacks to infer not only what devices reside inside a household (device fingerprinting), but also what higher-order activities users may be performing, for example, inferring whether a user is listening to CNN newsfeed or interacting with a specific their-party voice application, ii) help determine how data can be harvested from IoT devices, and iii) elicit security and privacy concerns from users in using IoT devices. 

This project has made significant progress toward enhancing the transparency of IoT devices. Through this project's funding, we have built an IoT testbed compromising around 30 off-the-shelf IoT devices. In addition, we have an infrastructure to automatically collect and label data from IoT devices. We are also sharing certain datasets publicly on our website. The IoT testbed enabled us to determine the feasibility of fingerprinting IoT devices and analyze the generalizability of such fingerprinting techniques across different real-world data sets. We have also developed methods to determine spatiotemporally stable features and showcased how targeted fingerprinting attacks can be carried out on specific devices with limited training data. We also investigated the security and privacy flaws of emerging voice interfaces such as Amazon Alexa. Our analysis reveals several limitations in Alexa's application vetting process. These vulnerabilities were disclosed to Amazon, and Amazon is currently supporting some of our ongoing projects in this space. 

Beyond these works, this project led to additional investigations related to the security and privacy of emerging IoT devices, including;

 

  • We analyzed the availability and effectiveness of existing security and privacy indicators or a lack thereof on emerging voice interfaces like Amazon Alexa. We found that users cannot distinguish between native and third-party applications and also cannot correctly determine which applications will be automatically activated through the voice interaction. 

 

  • We also conducted user studies to elicit peoples' attitudes and concerns towards adopting IoT devices. We collected responses from 232 participants from three different geographic regions (United States, Europe, and India) and showcased the similarities and differences in perceptions and concerns between adopters and non-adopters. Based on our findings, we provide recommendations to reduce users' concerns about adopting IoT devices and thereby enhance user trust in adopting IoT devices.

 

  • Additionally, we also designed a novel hand gesture recognition system for smart home voice assistants using only the built-in microphones and speakers. Our proposed approach can act as a second-factor authentication (2-FA) for performing specific sensitive operations like confirming online purchases through voice assistants. Our analysis showed that our approach can not only successfully thwart impersonation attacks but can do so while incurring very low overheads and is compatible with modern voice assistants.

 

This work has also had a significant training impact. Two Ph.D. students who were funded through this project are currently making progress towards obtaining PhDs. This project also supported two Master's students, both of whom have graduated and joined industry. Furthermore, the datasets from the IoT testbed are regularly used in undergraduate and graduate class projects to train the next generation of the STEM workforce.
